Vocabularies.Definition: n. any of a group of plants or animals produced from the cells of a single ancestor and therefore exactly the same as it is 克隆 v.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Researchers produced clones from adult mice in 1998.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. a young sheep 羊羔
a.  beginning to lose hair on the head 开始秃顶的 bald having no or little hair on the head 秃顶的
n. 胚胎学家
n. 怀孕（期）
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. It would be wiser to cut out all alcohol during prenancy.

Vocabularies.Definition: bring forth; create, originate 生（孩子）；产生
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Although a mother panda often gives birth to two cubs, she usually abandons one of them without attempting to care for it.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. an expensive French white wine with bubbles in it 香槟酒
n.  兽医
in every respect; exactly 在各个方面；完全
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. I felt for all the world as if I was still a child.

Vocabularies.Definition: vt. spread things or people in various separate places over an area 散布于 n. a small round mark 点
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. From the above we could see the trees dotting the landscape.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  创造（物）
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. The bathroom is entirely my own creation.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. a uniting or being united; combination 结合；联盟
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Labor unions bargain with employers to determine issues such as wages, conditions of work, and worker security.

Vocabularies.Definition: (pl. sperm or sperms) n. 精子
n. （牛、羊等的）乳房
n.  a very small unit of living matter 细胞 e.g. Soap destroys the cell walls of bacteria.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.

Vocabularies.Definition: v. (cause to) join together 融合；合并 e.g. Genes determine how we develop from the moment the sperm fuses with the
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  a unit in a chromosome which controls inherited characteristics 基因 e.g. Genetics is the study of the function and behavior of genes.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.

Vocabularies.Definition: go and live; move into (a certain position) 住进，栖居； 进入（某个位置） e.g. The hunter took up his quarters in a hut.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  the fact of living in a particular place 居住 e.g. More immigrants were admitted to the United States for permanent residence in those years.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.

Vocabularies.Definition: a.  exactly alike or equal; the very same 一模一样的；同一个 e.g. The journalist David Rorvik wrote a true story of a billionaire's quest to produce a son identical to himself.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.

Vocabularies.Definition: ad. concerning genes 遗传上
n.  双胞胎之一 e.g. He has a twin brother and a younger brother.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.

Vocabularies.Definition: ad.  in advance; earlier 事先 e.g. Catherine got married without telling anyone beforehand.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g.

Vocabularies.Definition: be against 反对 oppose vt. express strong disapproval with the aim of preventing or changing a course of action; resist 反对
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. They are strongly opposed to the presence of American troops in this region.

Vocabularies.Definition: a. concerned with the theory of a subject; based on theory 理论的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. With his brilliant theoretical work, Albert Einstein revolutionized 20th-century physics.

Vocabularies.Definition: as far as basic principles are concerned 原则上
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. In principle, clones may even be essentially immortal, dying only from disease or the deterioration of the environment.

Vocabularies.Definition: a. causing sb. to feel upset, insulted or annoyed 冒犯的，无礼的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Minority groups are protected from hateful and offensive speech and actions on campus.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. 实用观点；实用主义
n. a settlement in which each side gives up some demands 妥协 v.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. In order to reduce carbon monoxide emissions from motor vehicles but at the same time develop the industry, a compromise was reached.

Vocabularies.Definition: ad. in relation to what is considered right behavior; according to right standards of behavior 道德上 moral a.
vt. cause trouble, suffering or discomfort to, esp. continually or repeatedly使痛苦，给……造成麻烦 n. an infectious disease that kills many people 瘟疫
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. He suffered severe back injuries, which plagued him to this day. Millions of people died of plague and famine.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  the human race 人类
n.  the possibility of sth. happening or being developed 潜力 a.  that can, but has not yet, come into being; possible 潜在的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. The potential for abuse of genetic engineering has presented society with many ethical and legal controversies.

Vocabularies.Definition: vt. allow sth. that one does not like to happen or continue; put up with 容忍
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Drugs on campus would not be tolerated.

Vocabularies.Definition: a. belonging to times that are long past 古代的，古老的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Furniture designs have reflected the fashion of every era from ancient times to the present.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. excessive pride in one's appearance, achievements, etc. 自负，虚荣
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. The girl's vanity surprised me.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. a person who makes a gift of money, food, etc. for a good cause 捐赠人
(also catalogue) n. a complete list of items 目录
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Users outside the library can access millions of bibliographic records, including the entire card catalog, through the Internet.

Vocabularies.Definition: v. make (sb.) very frightened 使恐惧，使惊吓
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Flying has terrified some people since the terrorists attack on the World Trade Center.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  a close or exact copy of sth. 复制品
n. a game of chance; any undertaking that involves chance selections 抽签；碰巧的事，难于计算的事
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Which judges are assigned to a case is always a bit of a lottery.

Vocabularies.Definition: ad. under normal circumstances; ordinarily 正常地；通常
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. During 26 years of research on sharks I have found them to be normally unaggressive and even timid toward man.

Vocabularies.Definition: a. that can not be predicted 不可预测的
n.  a combination of two or more things or styles 混合（物）
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. A mixture of cultures from around the world is reflected in the street festivals and ethnic celebrations in New York City.

Vocabularies.Definition: a. very intelligent; extremely clever 才华横溢的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. The Sixteenth CPC National Congress is a brilliant success in the history of the Party.

Vocabularies.Definition: vt.  have features or qualities from an ancestor; receive (money, property, etc. of an ancestor) 因遗传而获得（特性等）； 继承
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Although all humans share the same set of genes, individuals can inherit different forms of a given gene, making each person genetically unique.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. the state or quality of being pure 纯净，纯洁
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. They worried about the purity of tap water.

Vocabularies.Definition: n.  freedom from sin or moral wrong; harmlessness 清白；无害
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. The accused man proved his innocence of the crime.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. a written or spoken remark giving an opinion 评论 v.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. There has been no comment so far from the police about the bomb attack happening yesterday.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. (a person who has) exceptionally great creative ability 天才
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Thomas Edison is considered a genius of invention.

Vocabularies.Definition: a. concerning atoms or the energy released by them 原子（能）的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. On August 6, 1945, the United States dropped an atomic bomb on Hiroshima, Japan.

Vocabularies.Definition: set free; release 释放
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Don't let that dog loose in the yard, as it will terrify the kids.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. a strong desire to know and learn 好奇心
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Science museums stimulate curiosity and allow people to learn at their own pace.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. an expert in physics 物理学家
n.  the smallest unit of an element that can take part in a chemical reaction 原子
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. A molecule of water is made up of two atoms of hydrogen and one atom of oxygen.

Vocabularies.Definition: a. having or involving many layers 多层次的
v. program again or differently 重新编程
v. remove tissue or an organ from one person or animal and put it into another; remove a growing plant with its roots and plant it elsewhere 移植；移栽 n. transplantation n.
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. To repair injuries such as burns, skin is sometimes transplanted from one area of the body to another.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. 骨髓
n.  白血病
make a sudden violent attack at with blows or words 猛击；严厉斥责
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. It seemed that he was going to lash out at the saleswoman, but he controlled himself.

Vocabularies.Definition: a. protected against through the body's natural resistance 免疫的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. The health of the body is dependent on the immune system's ability to recognize and then destroy bacteria and viruses.

Vocabularies.Definition: v. (cause to) combine （使）合并，（使）融合
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. In the great melting pot like New York City cultures are merged and traditions lost.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. 技术员
n. 蛋白质
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Fish is a main source of protein.

Vocabularies.Definition: a. of or at an early stage of development 原始的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. An examination of two fossils reveals that a primitive human species had arrived in Asia from Africa about 2 million years ago.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. a young animal or plant in the very early stages of its development 胚胎
intend when starting; begin 起初意图；开始
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Peter didn't start out to apply for Yale University -- it just happened that way.

Vocabularies.Definition: become gradually as time passes 长成
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. With the construction of the highways, the village is growing into a town.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. the amount (of bread, etc.) produced at one baking; a number of things taken as a group; lot 一批制成品；一组，一群
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. Harvard University biologist Dick Estes supplied a large batch of lion photographs taken from 1963 to 1965.

Vocabularies.Definition: a. very difficult to believe or imagine 不可思议的 conceive  v. form an idea, a plan, etc. in the mind; imagine 构想，设想
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. It is inconceivable that a thing can both be and not be.

Vocabularies.Definition: n. 肾
n. 肝脏
a. without limit; very great 无限的
a. of or based on a hypothesis假说的，假设的
Vocabularies.Paraphrase: e.g. This is a purely hypothetical question.

Vocabularies.Word: Gina Kolata       吉纳 · 科拉泰
Roslin       罗斯林(苏格兰地名)
Ian Wilmut      伊恩 · 威尔穆特
Dolly      多利（ 文中指克隆羊名）
John Bracken     约翰 · 布雷肯
Prometheus   （希腊神话） 普罗米修斯
Linda Pastan     林达 · 帕斯坦
Oppenheimer    奥本海默（1904-1967，美国物理学家，曾任美国研制原子弹的 "曼哈顿计划" 实验室主任）
Hiroshima     广岛 （日本港市，1945年8月6日美国在此投下第一颗原子弹）
Nagasaki     长崎（日本港市，1945年8月9日美国在此投下原子弹）
